About Me

  • 2007-2011

    Miami University

    B.S. Botany, Environmental Science

    I spent four years as an undergraduate in Richard Moore's lab studying population genetics of X/Y gene pairs in dioecious papaya

  • 2011-present

    University of Georgia

    Ph.D, Plant Biology

    I am currently a 4th year PhD candidate working with Jim Leebens-Mack



  • Curriculum Vitae

    Click asparagus for CV
    Updated September 2014

Research

My interests are broad, but encompass skills learned in the lab, the greenhouse, and at the terminal

Sex Chromosomes

I am using a suite of reverse genetic, sequencing, and bioinformatic strategies to identify gender determination genes on the garden asparagus Y chromosome

Polyploidy

Whole genome duplications have run amok in the flowering plants. I enjoy taking phylogenomic approaches with genome and transcriptome data to identify these events in big trees.

Basal Angiosperms

The basal angiosperms are a particularly special group of angiosperms. I am especially interested in Amborella trichopoda, the most basal extant angiosperm. And it's dioecious, too!

Team Asparagus

A lot of talented people are working on the Asparagus Genome project together

Jeremy Ray

Senior, Plant Biology.
Comparative genomics of sex-linked genes

Shayan Agha

Sophomore, Economics/Pre-med.
Performing FISH-based analysis of sex-linked genes

Dat Hoang

M.S Microbiology (2012).
Virus Induced Gene Silencing in Asparagus

Saravanaraj Ayyampalayam

PhD Chemistry (1999)
